author: nero_eth
content:
As 7623 implements it, 99% of the txs remain unaffected. What we really prevent is the worst cases where compressed max EL payload size is 27x the average. 
7623 wouldn't really change the median/average block size but more diffuses worst cases. With 9 blobs we'd be at 1.125 MiB max, 0.375 more than today. EIP-7623 can limit the worst case EL payload size by 0.72 MiB.

author: smartprogrammer
content: With the recent community push to increase the gas limit, I am very much in favor of implementing 7623 yesterday not in the future. We might face large block issues similar to what happened on sepolia previously which is not pleasant.

author: smartprogrammer
content: Additionally, we agreed to drop premerge history on may 1st, but if gas limit is raised without this eip, we will definitely need to do it way earlier which will put a lot of pressure on execution client devs given pectra's workload as well.

author: funnygiulio
content: Btw - is someone working here on an EIP pricings to make the precompile not bad? I am thinking fusaka would be a good scope for that

author: funnygiulio
content: anyway - as per our discussion at bangkok: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/9049 this limits the gas limit to transactions by 30 millions

author: lukaszrozmej
content: This would also help with worst case for parallel evm implementations

author: funnygiulio
content: yeah - mostly this deals with quadratic cases, now they do not grow indefinetely :)

author: funnygiulio
content: I actually would put this and 7623 (they are very easy) and then increase gas limit

author: funnygiulio
content: my feel from bangkok is that - most issues are addressed with these 2

author: marekm3498
content: Btw - is someone working here on an EIP

author: _shemnon
content: Paired with a block gas increase 7623 would make sense.  In isolation it is a net negative IMHO.

author: funnygiulio
content: in isolation it is not a net negative because the 3.5 MB block is an attack

author: funnygiulio
content: you would still reduce the net negative - no reason why a malicious block should be allowed at all

author: funnygiulio
content: average block is 75kb  - spike is around 200ish kbs. 3.5 MB is clearly a well-crafted outlier

author: _shemnon
content:
In a Proof of Work world propagating a 3.5MB concerns me as it could be used to advance one of the variours chain split attacks, but in a Proof of Stake world what validator is going to waste their slot on a bad block? Not to mention the multipe that would be needed? It's all downside for the proposer.  Maybe if a block builder goes rogue but that would be the end of their buisniess.

Simply increasing a cost with no way to absorb it elsewhere will result in lower TPS, unless we can expect a change in the character of transactions as a result.
